column4: Hi all, I was wondering am I able to use my ubuntu network card driver for other linux distros i.e knoppix?
Maybe.
Did you compile the driver yourself?
No I didn't, when I installed ubuntu, the driver was already there.
Well, your other distribution might also auto-detect it.  If not, if your network card is pretty common, there should be drivers available for it.

Thats the thing, it didn't , and I've searched a fair bit for help with this and haven't had much luck, so I was going to try and use the ubuntu one. What would be the problem with that? Sorry, I'm kinda new to linux.
Well, Ubuntu is just particularly good at being user friendly.  There are other user-friendly distros out there: Try Suse or even Fedora
Who makes your card?
KDE beep sounds are horrible
cool
Sorry, it is intel
no problem
Some distros are more user friendly than others.  If you want to use Noppix, you might have to do a bit more work.
lol.  ;)
Sorry again, ok what type of work would be involved? Like writting your own drivers and stuff?
God no.  The worst case scenario for any sane person would be to find the most generic drivers for your chip and compile them yourself.
Most probably, though, you'll find a package of some sort.
Oh ok, that sounds ok. Basically I'm looking to try out another distro, a bit more hands-on than ubuntu, if you know what I mean. Any recommendations?
It really is down to taste.  Fedora is a very good place to start.  Good balance between ease-of-use and high configurability
Oh ok, I'll look into that. Would slackware be too much of a jump?
Depends how patient and how much of an aptitude for that kind of thing you have.   Fedora is a good step.  You can learn a great deal from it.
Ok cool, I'll try Fedora out. Thanks very much for your help, appreciate it.
No problem.  :)  Good luck.
